Posts.Title: Brazil nuts bomber410 neat

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 08:20PM angied808 wrote: It is really not bad at all.  I was surprised.  Frankly having the fluid in there impeding your breathing is worse.  The wikipedia entry is helpful for getting an idea in your mind of what it's like.  The only painful part is when they freeze the area of your back, but that's not too bad, and then you don't feel anything after that.  I had a bit of discomfort for a day or two after - maybe the lung re-adjusting to having all that room to expand? I don't know - but it was worth it.  It will be ok! en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thoracen...
Posts.Title: What should I expect from draining effusion? PJB mungie

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 08:22PM angied808 wrote: Sorry I couldn't get it to hyperlink - can you cut and paste the wikipedia link? It is pretty quick, they drained 1.5L from my lung in less than 10 minutes.  I'd say it would be good to have someone to take you home but you will be fine.  I was good to walk around and everything afterwards. It will go well and be over in a jiff Paula!

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 01:05PM angied808 wrote: I've flown a number of times with my arm wrapped.  Every time they have been fine and just swabbed it for traces of explosives.  Most of the time they have been great and asked first if it would hurt if they swabbed the arm.  I think for the most part (disgruntled employees aside) it's easier to bandage at home and let them deal with it.  Worst they can do is ask you to take it off...

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2007 03:11PM angied808 wrote: people are incredibly judgmental.  i think i didn't realize it until i got cancer and then i really noticed what comes out of people's mouths.  at the moment i am told that i should be exercising by several people - the same people who see me sleeping 12 hours a day and limping around from bone pain.  have i mentioned none of them have exercised a day in their life?
Posts.Title: Have u ever encountered anyones attitude without BC? Ter EnergizerBunny

Posts.Content: angied808 wrote: I had 15 nodes removed from my right axilla in 2007 along with the full gamut of treatment.  I had 2 years cancer free, then was diagnosed with cancer in my left axilla (19+ nodes - 20 removed) with a completely different pathology but no tumor, so it's never been clear whether it's a recurrence or new primary.  It is very aggressive again, however.  During treatment I developed skin mets in my left axilla and had extensive radiation. I've been on Xeloda and Tykerb for 9 months, chemo for about 14 months total.  Tumor markers dropping. The past 2 months the lymphedema in my left arm has gotten worse, and despite treatment by my PT, I have stabbing constant pain in my axilla and arm bones in BOTH arms.  However I had a scan in November that came out NED.  My Christmas gift from cancer was finding a swollen node in my neck. I am really worried something is spreading - has anyone ever experienced anything like this?  The pain really stinks. Angie Dx 8/2009, IDC, Grade 3, 19/20 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bilateral Axillary Pain angied808 angied808
